Demand for energy has increased globally due to population growth and socioeconomic development stemming from rapid industrialization and urbanization. This scenario worsens the dependence on energy resources and highlights the question regarding their availability, showing the fragility of non-renewable fossil fuels. In order to supply the growing world demand for energy and respond to environmental concerns, biodiesel was adopted as a mitigating solution to the problems arising from the burning of fossil fuels as it has a biodegradable, renewable and non-toxic character. Recently, many studies have given attention to the heterogeneous catalysts for the production of biodiesel, since some economic and technological problems were recognized in the production via homogeneous reaction. Among the studied catalysts, layered double hydroxides (LDH) have stood out for presenting adjustable properties according to the composition and methods of synthesis, which are directly associated with the structural, morphological and catalytic aspects of their oxides. This review article aims to elucidate the relationship between the structure, basicity, composition and catalytic activity of metal mixed oxides (MMOs) from LDHs. In addition, a comprehensive description is made of the advantages of using MMOs/LDH-based catalysts, of the reaction optimization parameters and of the regeneration and reuse processes of these minerals. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords LDHs Mixed metals oxides Catalysis Transesterification Biofuel 1 Introduction Biodiesel is assumed as one of the main alternative energy sources to old-fashioned fossil fuels. Among the most vital characteristics establishing biodiesel as prosperous substitute for diesel fuel include its biodegradable, renewable, sulfur-free and non-toxic character, which diminishing emissions of pollutants such as CO2, particulate matter and hydrocarbons by up to 67% [1–3]. Traditionally, transesterification-based processes based on the reaction of triglycerides (oils) with a short-chain alcohol in the presence of a homogeneous or heterogeneous catalyst are the predominant used processes for biodiesel production [1,4–6]. Nowadays, conventional production is carried out with homogeneous catalysts, such as sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide, and the main disadvantage is the stage of purification and neutralization of the formed biodiesel, which can cause serious environmental concerns. The purification step aims to isolate the desired products (biodiesel and glycerin) and remove undesirable compounds (catalyst, residual glycerin, soap and unreacted triglycerides) through successive washing and separation cycles that lead to the formation of a larger amount of contaminated water. This downstream processing impacts the product separation, the final production duration, the generation of waste and the final biodiesel yield, since a large part of the biodiesel formed is lost due to the formation of the emulsion resulted from the reaction saponification (hydrolysis of the esters and formation of the corresponding metallic carboxylates) [6–9]. The designing of process based on heterogeneous catalysis can possibly minimize these problems. Due to the catalysts insoluble characteristic, the products separation is facilitated avoiding the neutralization stage and, in many cases, the catalysts can be regenerated and reused. Therefore, several studies are focused on the research and development of solid and stable catalysts through simple and economical methods [6,10]. Commonly used heterogeneous catalysts are alkali metal oxides, supported alkali metals, hydrotalcites, zeolites and others, as shown in Table 1. Among these, lamellar double hydroxides (LDHs) have stood out for showing promising performance for the production of biodiesel due to its typical structural organization, composed of lamellar layers and an interlamellar region that promotes the total separation of charges between ions and cations, thus allowing easy functionalization and modulation of basic and textural properties as a result of changes via chemical and methodological composition [11,12]. In addition to enabling the production of biodiesel from unrefined raw materials that can have high acidity and high moisture content, reducing production costs by up to 70% [13]. LDHs are often applied after calcination in the form of mixed oxides. This and other changes in the structure of LDHs, such as the proportion of metals and types of interspersed anions, suggests a change in the physical and chemical properties that can affect the yield and quality of biodiesel produced. The interaction of these variables can influence the arrangement of basic sites that are the active catalytic sites [14]. In general, more attention is given to the analysis of structural, morphological and catalytic aspects of LDHs. However, despite the great effort dedicated to these studies, it is still not possible to establish a clear correlation between the structure, surface basicity, and composition of LDHs or derived mixed oxides and hence their catalytic activity. In addition, the reaction mechanism of transesterification and the arrangement of the basic active sites for the reaction is still a matter of discussion among the authors [15–17]. In this context, this review provides a description of the LDHs’ crucial physico-chemical characteristics, focusing more on the structural and morphological features, in order to improve the key properties of mixed oxides with an emphasis on the nature, density and resistance of the basic catalytic sites. The predominant attention of the discussion is about on how the parameters associated with the synthesis in order to obtain active, selective and stable catalysts. The parameters related with the transesterification reaction and its possible implications in biodiesel production were also evaluated, while leaching, regeneration and reuse processes were also discussed. Additionally, a survey of the advantages of heterogeneous catalysis and reactions catalyzed by mixed oxides/LDHs were carefully examined. The union of these mentioned parameters, as well as a deep discussion about them, present a cutting-edge stage for the understanding of the future of heterogeneous catalysis in the production of biodiesel and represent the filling of an important literature lack. 2 Heterogeneous catalysis for transesterification Heterogeneous catalysts can be classified as Bronsted or Lewis catalysts because they have acid/basic properties on their surface which can act as active catalytic sites. LDHs are classified as basic Lewis catalysts due to the electropositive character of the metal cations that make up their structure and provide active regions in the transesterification reactions in association with their oxide compounds [7,12,30]. LDHs have two metals in their composition, with the presence of the second metal to influence and intensify specific physical-chemical properties. It is also plausible the catalytic activity to vary depending on the chemical composition (type and proportion of metals) and calcination temperature [8,12,31]. For instance, the role of the basic sites as well as of other physical-chemical properties of mixed oxides in the transesterification reaction has been widely studied and mentioned in several scientific works, such as from Di Serio et al. [30], Cantrell et al. [32], Boey et al. [33], Pérez et al. [34], Shumaker et al. [28], Xie et al. [35], Navajas et al. [36], Qin et al. [37] and Sankaranarayanan et al. [38]. The mechanisms that govern the functioning of heterogeneous catalysts in the transesterification reaction have not been fully clarified. However, it is known that the reaction is developed at specific points of the solid catalyst surface, called catalytic sites, where firstly adsorption occurs and hence the reaction rate can be controlled by mass transfer phenomena. On the other hand, the biggest divergence between the authors, when studying the reaction mechanism, occurs when trying to explain the initiation phase of the heterogeneous reaction. A study carried out by Hájek et al. [15] for the production of biodiesel via methanol, proposed several initiation mechanisms for the formation of methoxide ions (first stage of the reaction), with the explanations to include: i) formation of a more electrophilic species; ii) formation of the methoxide anion resulting from the reaction between the methanol-oxygenation and the methanol-hydroxide ion; iii) a mechanism based on the adsorption of methanol at the Lewis Base site of the catalyst and formation of oxygen anion or iv) activation of methanol on the surface and formation of two types of methoxide species. More information regarding the possibly involved mechanism of the heterogeneous transesterification reaction can be found in the works reported by Hincapié et al. [5], Di Serio et al. [30], Boey et al. [33], Prado et al. [39], Kouzu et al. [40], Yan et al. [9] and Montanari et al. [41]. A conclusive and interesting transesterification mechanism was proposed by Kouzu et al. [40] that contemplates the initialization stage of the basic heterogeneous catalyst. In the reaction shown in Fig. 1, step 1 describes the abstraction of the proton of an alcohol by the basic sites to form the methoxide anion. In step 2, the methoxide anion attacks the carbonyl carbon in a molecule of the triglyceride to form an alkoxycarbonyl intermediate that decomposes into two molecules: ester (biodiesel) and diglyceride. Finally, in step 3, the oxygen from the diglyceride anion attacks the proton attached to the base, leading to regeneration of the catalytic site. Thereafter, a new series of reactions begins with diglycerides (cycle 2), with steps 1, 2 and 3 also to take place for the formation of a monoglyceride and another ester molecule, which passes to cycle 3 and again through steps 1,2 and 3 until the final formation of another ester and glycerol molecule. The three cycles form the global reaction of transesterification, indicated at the end of the figure. According to the this mechanism, it is possible to support that the stoichiometry of the reaction requires three moles of alcohol for each mole of triglyceride (oil). However, as the reaction has a reversible character, an excess of alcohol is usually used in the reaction medium to promote the displacement of the chemical balance in favor of the formation of the products, increasing the yield. The main products of the reaction and in greater quantity are esters of fatty acids (biodiesel) and glycerol, with diglycerides and monoglycerides being intermediate products [8,38]. On a macro scale, it should be noted that the system is actually a three-phase mixture of biodiesel / glycerol + alcohol / catalyst. The catalyst is the only solid component and, therefore, can be easily separated from the reaction products. In addition, the products formed in a heterogeneous transesterification, biodiesel and glycerol are pure, avoiding the occurrence of saponification. Thus, the heterogeneous catalysis simplifies the biodiesel production process and, ideally, downstream steps are not required for aqueous biodiesel treatment: neutralization and purification. Besides, the catalyst can be recycled and reused easily [6–8,30]. Although, it is worth mentioning that many solid catalysts can result in leaching phenomena. A partial solubilization can occur, leading to the deactivation or affecting the catalytic activity after a few reaction cycles. In the case of leaching, it is necessary the biodiesel purification, and this would decrease the competitiveness of heterogeneous against homogeneous catalysts [3,14,39]. Leaching of metal-based catalysts has not been generally studied. The few studies that address this theme presents extremely low leaching results, as can be seen for example in the works carried out by Bálsamo et al. [12], Navajas et al. [11], Hájek et al. [14], Hájek et al. [15] and Capek et al. [16]. Another relevant factor for evaluating the catalytic efficiency, which also provides evidence that the reaction has gone through all the reaction cycles in a satisfactory manner, is the evaluation of the quality of the final product – biodiesel. The produced biodiesel must be evaluated based on international standards that establish the quality parameters of pure biodiesel (B100) and its mixtures with petroleum diesel (BX). Currently, the standards of the American Society for Tests and Materials (ASTM) and European Standards are the best known and serve as a reference for other standards. Among the parameters established by the standards are: the physical and chemical characteristics of biodiesel (cetane index, flash point, viscosity, density and others) and parameters related to the chemical composition and purity of the alkyl esters of fatty acids (quantidade de mono-, di-, e triacylglycerides, ester content, free and total glycerin, iodine index, etc.) [42]. Several methods for quantifying esters are cited in the literature, with the techniques vary between gas chromatography (GC) [10], gas chromatography coupled with mass spectroscopy (GC-MS) [43], Fourier transform infrared spectrum (FTIR) [44], hydrogen nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) [38,39] in order to estimate the percentage by weight of mass [27]. Nevertheless, for the purpose of standardization and commercialization of the product, the ester content is formally instituted by the standard EN 14103 which provides a minimum content in biodiesel esters of 96.5% (mass) evaluated by gas chromatography (GC). Regarding the quality of biodiesel, it is worth mentioning that the conversion does not vary solitary depending on the reaction, since other factors can contribute to the formation of biodiesel, such as: molecular structures of the constituent esters, presence of contaminants from the raw material, production process, storage of biodiesel, among others [45]. 3 Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) LDHs originally consists of two metallic cations (di- and/or tri-valents) that form the double lamelar layer, and the interlamelar region is filled essentially with water molecules and anions [46–50]. The general formula is given by [M2+ (1−x)M3+ x(OH)2]x+. [Ax/n]n−·mH2O; where M2+ is a divalent metal, M3+ is a trivalent metal, An- is the interleaved anion with “n-” to be the charge, and “x” representing the atomic ratio M3+/(M2+ + M3+) ranging from 0.1 to 0.5. Although, there are indications that the pure phases of LDH form occur only for x values in the range of 0.20–0.34; outside this range individual metal hydroxides or metal salts are predominantly created. For the formation of LDH is still required a ratio of M2+/M3+ ranging in the range of 1–6 [11,15,51]. Structurally, LDHs derive from the mineral clay brucite, which general formula is Mg(OH)2. In the formation of LDH based on brucite, a fraction of divalent metal (M2+) is isomorphiously replaced by a trivalent metal (M3+), causing a positive residual charge on the lamellae. This positive residual charge is compensated by the water and anions that fill the interlamelar region, promoting the stacking of the lamellae and giving rise to the structure of the LDH [5]. In the lamella, the cations M2+ and M3+ are evenly distributed in the hydroxide layers and are accommodated in the centers of an octahedral structure [17,51]. A schematic representation of the LDHs structure is shown in Fig. 2, where the can be seen the basal spacing of the unit cell of the LDHs which is the distance between the beginning of one lamella to the end of the other and varies depending predominantly with the size of the interlamellar anion. Either the unit cells of the di- and tri-valent metal hydroxide can be hexagonal or orthorhombic, although for the later case the ratio of M2+/M3+ required be equal to 1 [17]. Stabilization of the LDHs structure is possible due to electrostatic attraction forces between the lamellae (positive) and the interlamelar anions (negative). Therefore, the ratio of M2+/M3+ defines the density of the lamellae charge and, consequently, the amount of anions between the gills/lamellas. This relationship has a significant impact on the physicochemical properties of the material, such as crystallinity, porosity and/or ion exchange efficiency [52]. A wide variety of LDHs can be prepared from a extensive combination of metal cations and interlamelar anions, but metallic cations are required to have an octahedral structure with atomic radius preferably located in the range of 0.50–0.74 Å in order to obtain the required stability of the structure. Regarding the atomic radius of the anionic species, it is required to be in a range from 3 to 50 Å, filled by anions from organic and inorganic origin. Considering the inorganic anions, there is an order of interaction with the lamelar layer that facilitates the interleaving of these species given to follow CO3 2- > OH- > F- > Cl- >Br- > NO3 - > I- [52–54]. The extensive variety of anionic species that can be interleaved gives LDHs important potential for technological applications in several areas of knowledge, which allows their use as anionic exchangers, adsorbents, catalysts, catalyst supports, drug delivery agents, in the synthesis of advanced ceramic materials and in the preparations of modified electrodes [5,52,55]. In Table 2 are summarized the possible cations, which, by meeting structural criteria, can be used in the synthesis of LDH and the possible anions that can occupy the interlayered domain. The synthesis methods of conventional LDHs can be categorized into direct and indirect. In direct methods, solutions of metals and anions are used to form the structure of LDHs, in this group the co-precipitation methods are present [56], hydrothermal synthesis [57], electrochemical synthesis [58], urea hydrolysis [59] and sol-gel method [60]. In the case of indirect synthesis, the new LDHs are formed from the replacement of the interlamellar anion of a precursor LDH, and can be carried out by ion exchange in solution, ion exchange with protonation of the interlamellar anion of the precursor and regeneration of the calcined precursor [17]. There are also alternative and new methods, which seek simpler means of synthesis or seek to improve the structural properties of anionic clays. Among them, one can quote method of mechanochemical synthesis [61], a method in which one of the cations is iron eluting from steel balls in a rotating mill topochemical technique [62,63], an oxidative intercalation method and laser ablation technique [64], associated with the use of pulsed laser synthesizing LDHs with ultra-thin nanosheets in deionized water. The coprecipitation method (or salt-base method or titration method) is the most used in LDH preparations. In this method, two solutions are used, one containing the divalent and trivalent cations and the other containing hydroxide and the anion to be intercalated. The method presents two possible methodological approaches: co-precipitation at constant pH and at variable pH. Synthesis at constant pH occurs when the two solutions are added concomitantly, while at variable pH the cation solution is titrated over the alkaline solution until reaching the desired pH [17,46,51]. To achieve compounds with good structural organization and phase purity, an additional hydrothermal treatment may still be required aiming to give better crystallinity to the precipitate. Despite the diversity of existing synthesis techniques to produce LDHs, it is even difficult to form a clay with high purity and without contamination [46]. For more details on LDH synthesis methods and their characteristics, it is recommended to consult more specific studies, such as Crepaldi and Valim [17], Vaccari [51] and Cavani et al. [65], since that aspect is beyond the scope of this article as we focus on using LDHs for catalytic applications. 4 Evaluation of the control of variables in the production of biodiesel In this session, the main aspects that contribute to the formation of biodiesel from mixed oxides/LDHs will be examined. In this sense, the following are decisive for a good conversion: a) aspects that influence the formation of mixed oxides (preparation and structural variables) and b) transesterification reaction conditions (catalyst quantity, time, temperature, etc.). The response factor of the two steps is the conversion into biodiesel obtained from different oilseeds. 4.1 Influence of the catalyst preparation The physical and chemical properties of mixed LDHs oxides directly interfere in the yield and quality of biodiesel produced, and therefore its relationship with transesterification has been extensively studied. These properties are often tunable towards specific structural criteria by modifications made on variables that influence the formation of LDHs precursors of mixed oxides [11,66]. The surface properties of mixed oxides are influenced by various synthesis conditions (pH, temperature, concentrations, rate of reagent addition, aging time) and used synthesis methods (coprecipitation, hydrothermal, salt-oxidomethod and others) [67]. Vaccari [51] divided these variables into two categories: 1) preparation variables (pH, precipitation method, precipitation temperature, reagent concentration, aging, washing and drying and presence of impurities) and 2) structural variables (cation size, value of x [M3+/ (M3+ + M2+)], stereochemistry of cations, cation mixture, nature of balancing anions, amount of water between layers, morphology and size of crystals). To produce the catalysts and use them in the transesterification reaction, the calcination process can be added as a preparation variable because, after calcination, the catalyst is activated and takes the form of mixed oxides. The properties of mixed oxides mutually depend on the composition of their precursor and the calcination conditions, and the interaction of these variables results in modifications that are responsible for textural alterations and redistribution of basic sites (effects). Nevertheless, the other preparation variables, such as aging time, temperature, pH and others, are also related, to a lesser degree, with the properties of the oxides, since the characteristics of these oxides are consequences of the original material. Although calcination promotes structural changes from the formation of metastable crystalline and amorphous phases, the homogeneous interdispersion of thermally stable elements is maintained leading to the formation of finely dispersed and restructured mixed oxides [51,65,67]. Structural modifications can be evaluated using conventional analytical techniques, the most used in this area of concentration are: powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (EDX), thermogravimetric analysis (DTA/TG), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Transmission electronic microscopy (TEM), nitrogen adsorption, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), Hammett indicators (H_) and programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) [38,46,66]. Next, the most relevant points in the study of mixed oxides/LDHs are highlighted, considering the main preparation variables and the effects they produce on catalysts. 4.1.1 LDHs Calcination The calcination process of lamellar double hydroxides triggers the reorganization of the structure at high temperatures, which causes the transfer of trivalent cations from the octahedral sites to the tetrahedral sites, promoting the isomorphic substitution of the dimetallic cations in the mixed oxides. This rearrangement generates an excess of positive charge in the structure that is compensated with the generation of two types of defects resulting from this incorporation: cationic vacancies and/or inclusion of interstitial oxygen in the structure, forming the corresponding metallic oxides [3,16,35,68,69]. The calcination comprises the stages of dehydration (moisture), dehydration (interlayer water) and decarbonation leading to the formation of the corresponding mixed oxides [34,70]. However, the decarbonation step will be effectively present in LDH with intercalated carbonate ions, presenting similar ion removal processes for other ions between the lamellae. Thus, the LDHs gradually lose interlayer water during thermal treatment, then dehydroxylate and decarbonate to a significant amount, resulting in the development of a mixed oxide with a 3D network ( Fig. 3). The calcination evolution and the resulted effects on the material's physicochemical features can be accompanied by several characterization analyses: TGA/DTG, DRX, FTIR, SEM and SEM. Pérez et al. [34] used the TGA/DTG technique to evaluate the thermal decomposition of MgAl-LDH in the range of 300–800 K. The authors reported that the decomposition was characterized by two endothermic transitions, the first at 473 K attributed to water loss, and the second at 500–750 K associated with dehydrogenation and decarbonation ( Fig. 4a). In the XRD pattern obtained by Reyna-Villanueva et al. [44], it was observed that the disappearance of the characteristic peaks of LDH, corresponding to the bands located at 11.38,23.18 and 34.70° 2θ (or reflections (003), (006) and (012), respectively), resulting in the formation of mixed phases of Mg and Al oxides with the lamellae destruction (Fig. 4b). The peaks corresponding to MgO appeared at 34.70°, 42.58° and 62.58° and the peak corresponding to Al2O3 appeared at 22.88°, indicating Al3+ cations were highly dispersed in the MgO network without formation of spinel species (MgAl2O4). Xie et al. [35] reported the appearance of spinel at 2θ ≈ 19°; 31°; 37°; 59° and 65° in mixed oxides of MgAl pretreated at 1073 K in addition to the bands already described above (Fig. 4c). The effects of calcination temperature (450–1050 °C) on the basic and structural properties of Mg-Al mixed oxides was explored by Capek et al. [16]. They demonstrated that the catalytic activity and selectivity are correlated not only with the amount of basic sites, but also with MgO crystalline size, specific surface area and population of medium/strong base sites. It was concluded that the yield in esters was favored when a high-basic solid (226 μmolCO2/g) was used, a smaller MgO crystalline size (5.2 nm) and a high specific surface area (259 m2/g) reaching 77% of conversion into biodiesel esters. In the same study, the authors also observed: a) the increase in calcination temperature caused an increase in the crystal size that grew due to the formation of the spinel phase (MgAl2O4) and b) the surface area and the basicity had their maximums for Mg-Al calcinated to 550 °C. Thereby, it is evident that the calcination process leads to significant changes in the arrangement of the constituents of LDHs, promoting their activation and making them good catalysts from which improved characteristics arise, such as greater resistance of the active sites (concentration and basic strength) and larger surface areas. In this sense, several authors reported that there was no catalytic activity of non-calcined LDHs, Navajas et al. [11], Xie et al. [35] and Navajas et al. [36]. According to Navajas et al. [11] LDHs in their original formation have low basicity due to the presence of water molecules in their structure, which makes access to active sites for the reaction difficult, resulting in the inactivity of the material. 4.1.2 Basic sites and composition of LDHs As for the formation of basic sites, its mechanism can be better understood by analyzing a specific case. In a catalyst formed by mixed Mg- Al oxides, it is evident that calcination causes structural defects resulting from the incorporation of Al3+(Al2O3) dispersed in the MgO network to compensate for the positive charge generated. The ions O2- adjacent to Mg2+ or the defects generated by the incorporation of Al3+ in the structure are probably responsible to generate the active basic sites linked to low (OH-), medium (Mg-O pairs) and strong (O2−) basicity. At higher calcination temperatures (> 830 °C) the formation of spinel MgAl2O4 can also occur, which does not exhibit any particular catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction [16,35,44,51,72]. The composition of LDHs influences their catalytic capacity during the transesterification reaction, and this is mainly due to the variation in electronegativity of the metals used in the preparation of clays. Therefore, the basic resistance and density of the catalyst surface can be modulated via changes in the chemical composition (cations and anions) and in the molar ratio of cations that make up the precursor LDH [7,37,66,73]. Programmed CO2 desorption (CO2-TPD) and Hammet indicators are often used to assess the basicity of materials. The CO2-TPD method is generally used to identify Brönsted and Lewis basicity and provide information on the different types of basic sites and their distribution. While Hammet's indicators (H_) are qualitative methods that provide information about the basic strength of catalysts. [8,38]. Sankaranarayanan et al. [38] performed the synthesis by coprecipitation of CaAl, CoAl, LiAl, MgAl, NiAl and ZnAl-LDHs for the production of biodiesel from sunflower. Among the catalysts, the oxide of CaAl-LDH calcined to 700 °C showed higher activity (90%), the others did not show significant catalytic activity even with high surface areas. The authors related the catalytic activity to the distribution of the strong and weak basic sites of the catalysts. The catalyst CaAl3700-LDH it was the only one that showed three different desorption peaks: weak basic sites (220–390 °C), average basic sites (390–550 °C) and strong basic sites (600–780 °C) while the others did not show any peaks or had few characteristic peaks (CaAl-LDH calcined to 450 and 900 °C) as shown in Fig. 5a. Hammett's studies confirm that the CaAl-LDH oxide existed the presence of stronger basic sites with H_ in the range of 11–15, while the other catalysts showed H_ in the range of 7–11. Xie et al. [35] studied the catalytic activity of calcined hydrotalcite with different Mg-Al molar ratios from 2.0 to 4.0 for soybean biodiesel production. The catalytic activity improved substantially with the increase of the molar ratio of Mg/Al to 3.0; above this value, there was a decrease in conversion. This variation can be directly correlated to the total basicity determined by the titration in the presence of Hammett indicators, which demonstrated that the basicity of the solids varied from 7.2 to 15.0; having its maximum with the hydrotalcite produced with a Mg/Al molar ratio of 3.0 where it was possible to observe a conversion into biodiesel esters up to 67% (Fig. 5b). Studies by Bolognini et al. [74] demonstrated that the Mg/Al atomic ratio of 4 is in fact less basic, with lower density and basic resistance. The authors believe that the reason behind this is that the basic sites decrease due to the partial coverage of the MgO surface sites by segregation of the epinelic phase. But for the range 2.0 <Mg / Al < 3.5, the authors were unable to establish a proportionality relationship with basicity. However, they obtained a maximum basicity at a ratio of 3.5 (275 μmol/g) determined by the CO2-TPD method, close to the value obtained by Xie et al. [35]. In addition to the two mentioned techniques, other methodologies can be used to estimate the catalysts basicity: benzoic acid titration [36], retroaldolization of diacetone alcohol (DAA) [34] and point of zero charge (pHPZC) [44]. 4.1.3 Structural and morphological properties of mixed oxides/LDHs The structural and morphological properties are also related to the catalytic activity of the catalysts and are modified as a function of the variables used in the preparation of LDHs. Many studies address this issue as, Di Cosimo et al. [31] and Cantrell et al. [32]. In the studies of Ma et al. [27], it was suggested that a number of micropores formed after calcination of MgAl-LDH provided the basic sites for the transesterification reaction and the specific area and pore size were determinant for the good performance of the catalyst. Hájek et al. [14] synthesized mixed oxides of Mg-Al in different molar proportions (from 1.8 to 7.2), in order to study the effect of the molar ratio on basicity, size of MgO crystallite, specific surface area and leaching of the material during production of rapeseed biodiesel. The authors reported that the size of the MgO crystallite, surface area and the yield in esters, increased with the increase of the Mg/Al ratio pretreated at 450 °C; but that the concentration of basic locations decreases. In this study, the highest achieved reaction yield was 78% using a hydrotalcite with a basicity of 124 μmol CO2 / g, a specific surface area of 211 m2 / g and an MgO crystallite size of 6.5 nm. Leaching was considered negligible in this study. Shumaker et al. [28] produced soybean biodiesel using LiAl LDHs. SEM images of the catalyst indicated that changes in the structural variables and in the nature of the balance anions significantly influenced the morphology of these materials. The authors used Al (NO3)3·9H2O (0.4 M), LiOH·H2O (1.5 M) and Na2CO3 (0.08 M) for the preparation of the catalyst LiAl-1, Al2(CO 3)3 (0.5 M) and LiOH·H2O (4.8 M) for the catalyst LiAl-3. The LDH produced have different characteristics; one characterized by compact clusters of non-porous grains and the other characterized by platelets, where many were hexagonal ( Fig. 6). The LDH with higher lithium content (LiAl-3) showed better biodiesel conversion (83.1%). The results of Hsu et al. [75] corroborate this theory. The authors proved that the increase in magnesium content in the MgAl-LDH was able to change both the shape, due to variations in the thickness of the lamellae according to the size of the atomic ray employed, and the catalytic activity, due to the increase in the basic content inherent in the nature of the atoms. In the 5: 1 ratio of Mg /Al, the reaction yield increases dramatically from 7.6% in 2: 1% to 11.0% in 3: 1–65% in this proportion. This is due to the high basicity of the 5: 1 ratio – higher concentration of benzoic acid –, which concludes that the activity of the active site ends up being a more determinant parameter than necessarily the surface area for this type of reaction. On the other hand, the work of Perez et al. [31] evaluated the increase in aluminum content in the preparation of MgAl-LDH and concluded that these factors had no significant influence on the morphology of mixed oxides or on the selectivity of the reaction. Therefore, many authors have shown structural changes after the calcination process, it was reported that LDHs undergo an increase in surface area [28,34–36], increased basicity in intermediate calcination temperature (450–550 °C) [36,44] and increase in pore volume [28,44]. In constrast, Albuquerque et al. [76] defined, without significant effect, the calcination on the volume of pores and Xie et al. [35] showed a decrease in basicity for calcination temperatures below 400 °C above 600 °C. 4.1.4 Doping LDHs with metals LDHs can be doped with metallic cations to change their basic strength, making it possible to functionalize the catalytic action of these materials by inserting a third metal into the mixed oxide structure. This session evaluates several doping mechanisms carried out with LDHs and brings together the main discussions about the effects (basicity and textural properties) caused in catalysts, already discussed for conventional mixed oxides. The metal doping process is described in different ways in several references. Methods include direct syntheses such as co-precipitation method [7,12], where the reactants are mixed under the reaction conditions at constant or variable pH over a temperature range and method of solution combustion [10], a method that produces materials with low residual carbon content, high crystallinity and does not require the use of high temperatures, as in calcination. In this method, a urea-type initiator is applied as fuel in the solution, in a microwave oven and at low temperature, with the beginning of the reaction being characterized by a high release of smoke. Indirect methods of preparation with wet impregnations are also used. [12,37], a doping method that consists of mixing an LDH matrix structure with a solution containing the metals to be added, followed by the processes of vacuum evaporation, drying at 90 °C and calcination and impregnations by the incipient moisture method [77–79], where solids are mixed in certain proportions, dried and calcined. And finally there is the solid reaction method [4], which is based on solid mechanical mixing of reagents under conditions of sufficient temperature and contact time to react. There are reports in the specific literature of doping mixed oxides with K [4,77], Ce [12], La [12] e and other transition metals [80]. Bálsamo et al. [12] studied the influence of the basicity of mixed MgAl oxides doped with La and Ce. These metals were incorporated by co-precipitation (Lac and Cec) and wet impregnation (Lai and Cei) methods. For the first procedure, the authors used the co-precipitation method at constant pH, applying metallic nitrates of Mg2+, Al3+ and M3+, where M3+ represents Ce or La, directly in the preparation reaction. In the second procedure, the wet impregnation method was used, where the synthesis of co-precipitation for the calcined Mg-AL / LDH matrix was performed, and then the impregnation of this matrix with a Ce or La salt solution (10% w/w) followed by evaporation. Both synthesis methods satisfactorily promoted the incorporation of La and Ce. Basicity analyzes were performed by CO2-TPD. The dopings performed by the co-precipitation technique showed very low basic densities, around 0.70 and 0.8 μmol CO2.g−1, for doping with Ce and La, respectively. While the highest density of basic sites was attributed to the oxides incorporated by the impregnation method, with values of 4.6 and 3.45 μmol CO2.g−1 for samples impregnated with Ce and La, respectively. The highest basicity was attributed to the MgAlCei sample and was related to the highest yield of 77% monoglycerides. In this study, it was evident that basicity varied mainly with the method of synthesis and not with the type of metal incorporated. On the other hand, Qin et al. [37] reported that surface basicities varied with the addition of different metals. (Fe3+, Cu2+ and Zr2+), correlating the basic strength and density of the catalyst surface with its catalytic activity. Wang et al. [81] also mentioned that this basic modulation can be made from transition metals like Cr3+, Fe 3+, Cu2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+ and Zn2+. The authors found that the moderate and strong basic sites determined by the CO2-TDP method varied as a function of the transition metal added according to the following order: Mn2+ (191.0 μmol /g) > Cu2+ (167.2 μmol /g) > Co2+ (154.4 mol/g) > Ni2+ (149.2 μmol /g) > Zn2+ (139.5 μmol /g) > Fe3+ (129.2 μmol /g) > Cr3+ (123.0 μmol /g); relating to catalytic activity in a positive way. Previous investigations have also reported increased base site density in metal-modified catalysts such as Fatimah et al. [4], Limmanee et al. [7], Manríquez et al. [80] and Katekong et al. [78]. Other studies evaluated the changes in the textural properties of LDHs doped with metals. Manríquez et al. [65] evaluated the co-precipitation doping of Mg-Al/LDHs with transition metals Fe+2, Zn+2, Ni+2 e Cu+2. The authors found that the textural properties appeared to correlate with the ionic radius of the transition metal ions used in doping LDH. In samples doped with Fe+2, Ni+2 and Cu+2 it was observed that the surface area (253–204 m2/g), pore diameter (180–73 cc/g) and pore volume (1.14–0.37 Å) decreased with increasing ionic radius. The ionic radius was given as: Fe+2 (0.61 Å) < Ni+2 (0.69 Å) <Cu+2(0.73 Å). Nevertheless, in samples doped with Zn+2, that presented high relative surface area (234 m2/g), large pore diameter (134 Å) and pore volume (0.78 cm3/g), apparently they are not related to the ionic ray as observed in other metals. As expected, the morphologies in all doped materials also undergone significant changes. The Fig. 7 shows the differences between pure and doped with Cu+2 mixed oxide. Fig. 6a corresponds to the sample of MgAlO that appears in the form of rods with approximately 600 nm interconnected by the bodies, and with formation of disordered agglomerates, suggesting the indication of reasonable crystallinity by the edges and vertices presented, and Fig. 6b, which corresponds to a MgCuAlO sample [80], presented a plate-like morphology with low roughness, but with the presence of cracks and flaking between the ligand plates, suggesting a greater surface area [80]. The XRD patterns presented in Fig. 8 are related to the evaluation of KF-modified hydrotalcite for microwave-assisted biodiesel conversion loaded with 5%, 10%, 20% and 30% by weight of KF (KF5/HT, KF10/HT, KF20/HT and KF30/HT). There were no major structural changes of the material and the lamelar structure was preserved. The characteristic peaks of LDHs were maintained (2θ = 11.889° (003), 23.697° (006) and 35.015° (110)), suggesting a possible entrapment of KF molecules in HT. However, in samples with higher KF contents, it was possible to observe the emergence of new signals attributed to the crystalline phases KMgF3 (2θ = 32.027°, 45.93° and 68.15°) resulting from the interaction between KF and hydrotalcite [4]. Many studies show that these structural changes seem to positively affect biodiesel yield, such as, Fatimah et al. [4], Gao et al. [82] and Teng et al. [77]. Limmanee et al. [7] examined the catalytic activity of mixed CaMgZn oxides for the synthesis of palm kernel oil methyl esters. The authors concluded that the transesterification activity of the oxides was essentially determined by the types of metallic phases present in the mixed precipitates before their calcination. The presence of the metallic oxides CaO, MgO and ZnO gave the catalyst different basicities that promoted the reaction at different rates. The rate was exponentially related to total basicity. In this study, the yield of 97.5% by weight of FAME was achieved under optimized reaction conditions. In general, it is possible to attribute greater catalytic activity to the formation of doped mixed oxides, since the ability to support metal on the oxides allows controlling the basic properties of the catalysts. In addition to the conversion into biodiesel and the physicochemical properties, one way to evaluate the efficiency of the impregnation/doping process of these catalysts is to verify the occurrence of leaching and analyze the stability of the material produced. Harnandez et al. [59] analyzed the stability of the catalyst formed by ZnCuAl oxides prepared by hydrolyzing urea, the catalyst was stable for up to three reaction cycles, with a 6.5% reduction in biodiesel yield. The authors related the decay of catalytic activity to the partial segregation of metallic Cu to the catalyst surface, observed by XRD. Lu et al. [83] followed the catalytic activity of the mixed oxides CaFe, CaAl and CaFeAl produced by co-precipitation before and after the reaction. The leaching of metal ions was measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP) which demonstrates that the greatest loss of calcium ions occurred with the catalyst CaAl/LDH (60.77 ppm) while for the CaFe and CaFeAl catalysts only a small amount of Ca2+ leached into the reaction medium, 16.90 ppm and 12.95 ppm, respectively. The better stability of these last two catalysts was attributed to the presence of iron ions, which apparently strengthened the stability of the catalyst structure and improved its reusability. Presumably, the CaFeAl catalyst showed greater stability since it had the lowest level of leaching among the analyzed materials. In this sense, catalysts that were stable after doping or that did not report a significant presence of leaching were also obtained by Bálsamo et al. [12], Teng et al. [82] and Naderi et al. [10]. 4.1.5 General considerations on the preparation of mixed oxides/LDHs Table 3 brings together a series of studies of catalysts formed by mixed oxides/conventional LDHs and doped with metals applied to the production of biodiesel. Among the analyzed catalysts, the catalyst that showed the best performance was the catalyst formed by Ln-Mn prepared by the co-precipitation method and calcined at 600 °C. The oxides formed had high basicities and high conversions (99%) but a low surface area value. Another catalyst that proved to be very active was the catalyst formed by MgALK impregnating with K (10%) by the solid reaction method, the solids produced showed high total basicity reaching high conversions (98%), but also presented a low value for the surface area. High conversion results (81.8%) were also achieved by catalysts formed by Li-AL calcined at 450 °C and produced by co-precipitation. The catalysts showed high basicity and lower surface area pore volume. Thus, it is evident that the relationship between the basicity/structure/composition and catalytic activity of calcined LDHs is not yet well established, but some proportions have been presented. Capek et al. [16] suggested that only a small number of Brønsted base species are located at the platelet edges of hydrotalcite and that these are the active species for the reaction. They also suggested that calcination promotes the activation of catalysts, changing not only the amount of active sites, but also the distribution of weak, medium and strong basicity sites. However, the author highlights that the assignment of TPD peaks to individual basic sites is still a matter of discussion. Some authors associate the catalytic activity of oxides with total basicity, but not with basic resistance [7]. While others use the criterion of individual basic sites [14]. The role of morphological and structural properties in transesterification has also been extensively discussed in several papers. Di Serio et al. [84] pointed out significant differences in the catalytic activity as a consequence of the structural alterations of the catalysts. The authors proposed that mesoporous catalysts are more active than catalysts containing many micropores as it is more difficult for bulky triglyceride molecules to reach the basic catalytic sites within the micropores. Thus, it is possible to assume that in addition to a sufficiently high and improved basicity, the catalyst structure has to be adequate to ensure that the basic active sites are accessible on the catalyst surface to have a positive impact on biodiesel production. However, this correlation is extremely complex and still requires additional investigations that can substantiate its full understanding [15,83]. 4.2 Influence of transesterification reaction parameters The conversion of the transesterification reaction depends on the balance shift in favor of the ester’s formation. Sankaranarayanan et al. [38] warn regarding economic feasibility for producing biodiesel by heterogeneous catalysis. Highlighting that, one of the main bottlenecks is the production of competitive catalysts that operate under similar conditions or close to homogeneous and highly active conditions for the most diverse sources of triglycerides. Therefore, the optimization of the operational variables of the transesterification reaction is essential for the development and diffusion of heterogeneous catalysis. The literature indicates that the transesterification reaction suffers the effects of chemical variations: type of alcohol, necessary proportions of alcohol, type of catalysts, amount of catalyst, temperature and time of reaction, treated to follow. 4.2.1 Effect of alcohol/oil ratio Oil/alcohol initial molar ratio is one of the main factors that affects the efficiency of ester conversion, yield and operating costs of biodiesel production. The stochiometric requirement of the molar alcohol/oil ratio is 3:1. In practice, this molar relationship should be greater than the required the stochiometric ratio, aiming to cause the displacement of the reaction balance in favor of the products formation, since the reaction is reversible [8,27,44]. In heterogeneous catalysis, this excess of alcohol may be responsible for the catalytic sites regeneration and may positively influence the reaction rate, since as the products are removed from the catalytic surface, there is a direct reaction favoring [9,38]. To study the effect of the methanol/oil ratio, Reyna-Villanueva et al. [44] evaluated the optimization of biodiesel production from sunflower oil using 4% by weight of oxide Mg-Al as a catalyst, with a variation in the methanol/oil ratio equal to 4:1, 14:1 and 24:1, with 65 °C for a period of 30 min to 6 h, with the biodiesel yield as the response variable (FAME). The results of these studies confirmed that the yield increases with the methanol/oil molar ratio at any time of the reaction. Maximum FAME contents achieved with methanol:oil molar ratio 4:1, 14:1 and 24:1 were 72.91; 98.52% and 98.52%, respectively, reached after 6 h of reaction for the 4:1 and 14:1 ratios and 30 min for the 24:1 molar ratio. Similar results were obtained by Gao et al. [82], in their studies the FAME content increased as the methanol/oil molar ratio increased from 6: 1–12:1 with approximate yields of 89% and 98%, respectively, using 5% of the KF/Ca-Mg-Al catalyst at reflux temperature for 10 min. The authors associated this increase with the positive pressure effect caused by excess methanol on the reaction balance. 4.2.2 Effect of catalyst amount The amount of employed catalyst is another factor that deserves to be emphasized, since the catalyst offers the active sites for the reaction. It is expected that an increase in the amount of catalyst will increase the number of active sites to the same degree. The sites of strong basicity (O2-) extract H+ from alcohol to form the catalytic active center CH3O and initiate the reaction (induction step), promoting the progression of the reaction to the next steps. An excess of catalyst, on the other hand, can cause emulsification and elevate the viscosity, turning it difficult to access the active sites and even causing parallel reactions, thus decreasing yields, so it is also a parameter that should be optimized [27,38]. Limmanee et al. [46] used a series of mixed oxides of Ca, Mg and Zn with highly dispersed crystallites morphology prepared from co-precipitation at controlled pH (7, 8, 9 e 10) for biodiesel production from palm kernel with methanol. An optimized amount of catalyst equal to 6% towards 97.5% conversion was obtained. Even with a low methanol/oil ratio, the authors achieved high conversions. At lower or higher values, of 2% and 8% of catalyst, low yields on biodiesel (FAME) were obtained. The authors justified this variation to possible limitations of mass transfer, resulting from the agglomeration of the oxide particles. Parametric studies were also investigated by Navajas et al. [11] for the production of sunflower biodiesel using rehydrated Mg-Al hydrotalcites. The authors observed that for the fixed molar ratio of methanol/oil of 12:1 per 24 h the conversion increased from 51% to 62% and to 75% when the catalyst load increased from 2% to 4% and to 6% by weight, respectively. 4.2.3 Effect of temperature and reaction time Temperature and reaction duration are also significant parameters for transesterification reaction. Temperature variation affects thermodynamically the collision between molecules and active sites, while duration should be sufficient to reach chemical equilibrium [27]. An analysis of the influence of temperature and reaction time can be found in the work developed by Li et al. [87]. The authors studied the activity of the catalyst formed by Mg2CoAl oxides with an ethanol/oil molar ratio equal to 16:1. The experiments were carried out at 413, 433, 443, 453 and 473 K and observed for a period of 0–300 min. The results indicated a correction between temperature and increasing conversion to biodiesel, with yields approximately equal to 18%, 60%, 85%, 92% and 98%, respectively, reached in the maximum time. Lower conversions occur at lower temperatures as well and have been attributed to the conversion of intermediate species (diolein). As for the reaction kinetics, the same increasing relationship was observed, however, only the reaction conducted at 473 K seems to have reached chemical equilibrium in 180 min, as shown in Fig. 9. The optimization of these factors is important aiming to maximize biodiesel yield and minimize production operating costs. The optimization process can be combined with design of experiments and response surface methodology to determine favorable operating conditions. In addition to the optimization parameters mentioned, the conversion of biodiesel can be influenced by the quality of the raw material used. The use of unrefined and reused oils can increase the difficulty of processing biodiesel as they usually have high levels of free fatty acids (FFA) and moisture [13]. Commercial oils that undergo the refining process have FFA at lower levels, with acidity indices ranging between 0.5 and 3 mg KOH/g, outside this range it is not possible to guarantee that the reaction occurs completely [88]. The catalytic process can be substantially harmed by the high levels of FFAs because they react with the catalysts forming saponified products, presenting a series of inconveniences in the reaction system, such as consumption and deactivation of the catalyst. The presence of water, in turn, leads to the hydrolysis of oils into FFAs, further increasing the concentration of these acids in the reaction system. In these situations, the pre-treatment (esterification) of the oils is recommended to reduce the FFA content for subsequent application in transesterification, so the reaction is carried out in two steps [13]. However, catalysts formed from mixed oxides have shown promising results in transesterification using low-quality raw materials and the successful use of unrefined and reused oils in the production of biodiesel has often been reported in the literature, as shown in Table 4. The data in the table show that there is no great variation in the reaction parameters depending on the characteristics of the oils used, it can also be said that there is a certain similarity between the studied reaction conditions. However, data are still insufficient to establish exact and reliable limits on the degree of tolerance of these catalysts to the quality aspects of the oils used in the production of biodiesel. Table 4 shows an overview of the diversity of parameters used in the production of biodiesel with mixed oxides associated with the characteristics of the raw materials used. 5 Ability to regenerate and reuse LDHs The regeneration process of heterogeneous catalysts targets to recover the original activity of the disabled catalyst, in order to allow its reuse in the catalytic process and hence the entire process to be more sustainable. Catalyst stability is measured also based on its efficiency upon reusability, so the evaluation of the catalyst's life is a key resource to assess its practical application and economic impact [27,77,85]. Thereupon, the regeneration process of heterogeneous catalysts constitutes an important differential that aims to overcome the disadvantages of homogeneous catalysts that are soluble and can only be used once. As already discussed, although homogeneous catalysts are highly effective, they are extremely difficult to separate from the reaction mixture, and washing/purification methods should be used for their removal, making reuse and regeneration impossible [3]. There are several regeneration methods that can be applied for the recovery of mixed oxide-based catalysts. Usually, the easy-to-execute methods are preferable, such as washes (with water, methanol, ethanol or hexane) and catalyst filtration, followed by furnace drying [4,10,38] or recalcination [8,27] or even direct use after centrifugation of the reaction mixture [85]. The process of catalyst regeneration is discussed in various studies, and the catalytic stability upon regeneration for four studies can be observed in Fig. 10. Among the results of the performed regeneration tests presented in the Fig. 8, the studies from Naderi et al. [10], Nasreen et al. [85], Ma et al. [27] and Sankaranarayanan et al. [38] presented that the regeneration is efficient up to6 cycles. Nasreen et al. [85] synthesized La-Mn oxide by co-precipitation method and applied it to soybean biodiesel production. The catalyst was recovered and reused directly for up to 11cycles, with the conversion exceeding 90% until the 7 reuses of the catalyst, reaching 78.2% in the 11th cycle. After this cycle, the catalyst underwent another recovery process, being calcined at 600 °C for 90 min. After calcination, the catalyst showed greater activity with 84% conversion and then gradually decreased until 4 reuses, totaling 15 reuse cycles. In general, for a regenerative process to be considered successful, maintaining satisfactory catalytic activity, it is necessary that several other requirements are met. Among them, we can highlight most important the recovery of the original surface properties and conservation of the metallic phase. The process is carried out when the causes of the deactivation can be reversed. Plethora of reasons responsible for the deactivation of heterogeneous catalysts can be seen in Table 5. Characterization techniques can help to understand the mechanisms that lead to the deactivation of solid catalysts, since the activity of catalysts may be related to their basic forces and other properties [85]. Several authors have reported changes in basicity and/or structural features, after the completion of catalytic regeneration cycles. The basicity was studied by the authors Nasreen et al. [85] and Capek et al. [16]. Nasreen et al. [85] observed a decrease in the basicity of Hammett, with initial basicity in the range of 9,8 < H < 15,0 e final de H_< 9,8. Capek et al. [15] noticed small changes in basicity reflecting a low redistribution of basic locations. Gao et al. [68] used the combination of XRD and FTIR techniques to analyze the deactivation of the catalyst formed by K-Ca-Mg-Al/LDH. The XRD patterns indicated that there was no loss of the active crystalinity, suggesting that the deactivation originated by the adsorption of some reaction byproduct, glycerin, and decreased the effective contact surface, confirmed by the FTIR analysis that indicated the presence of the –OH groups of glycerin. Changes in specific surface area determined by N2 sorption were observed in the works developed by Nasreen et al. [85] and Ma et al. [27]. In the first study, it was observed that the difference between the area of the fresh and reused catalyst was 25.7 m2 /g and in the second study, it was 33 m2/g. Ma et al. [43] also observed a decrease in the average pore diameter that showed a difference of 1.8 nm and a decrease in the density of basicity with a difference of 0.2 μmol /m2 between the fresh and the reused catalyst, for the authors these structural differences were determinants for the deactivation of the catalyst. The morphology of the catalysts was mentioned in the studies developed by Teng et al. [77] and Nasreen et al. [85]. Teng et al. [77] analyzed the morphology of the K-MgAl / LDH samples using SEM in fresh and reused catalysts and found no obvious differences between the structures. The catalyst's morphology and particle size distribution were preserved for up to 5 regeneration cycles. In contrast, Nasreen et al. [85] observed notable morphological changes, the fresh La-Mn / LDH catalyst showed aggregates of particles with different sizes ranging from 1 to 20 µm, and the reused catalyst showed lumps or compact crystals, in addition to smaller aggregate particles ( Fig. 11). The authors attributed this difference to the change in the crystallinity of the material, later confirmed by the XRD method. The same authors also evaluated the content of La and Mn determined by EDS and observed a decrease in the content of La (9.36–6.27%) and Mn (10.23–6.12%). It was concluded, then, that the loss of the catalysts' regeneration capability could be associated with the loss of active metals or the loss of the surface area due to the adoption of organic compounds, such as fatty acids and glycerol, which can occupy the surface of these solids, causing in addition to changes in surface area, changes in morphology and layout and accessibility of the basic sites on the surface of these catalysts. 6 Advantages and disadvantages of LDHs for biodiesel production Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) have attractive properties for the catalysis area because they are compounds that allow easy functionalization. Its properties are adjustable and change due to its heterobimetallic nature and intercalation capability with periodicity at the nanoscale. This property gives it a distinctive characteristic, in relation to other catalysts, as they stand out mainly for their perfect structural ordering by promoting the complete separation of charges between the ions and the lamellar layers [8,11,12]. In particular, the mixed oxides that are formed from these minerals have modifiable basicity and considerably large surface area, which are the result of modifications in the type, proportion and valence of metals (tri and bivalent cations) of their precursor LDHs and of the process of heat treatment (calcination) applied [8,31]. Plenty of researches focused on heterogeneous catalysts formed from mixed oxides revealed a higher activity for different LDHs compared to other types of heterogeneous catalysts formed only by one type of metal [16,31,32]. Cantrell et al. [32] in their studies, examined the mixed catalysts formed by Mg-Al, and they observed that mixed catalysts have higher activity and selectivity than pure MgO for the transesterification of glyceryl tributyrate. The authors concluded that the lower activity of pure MgO could be associated with its low porosity compared to hydratalcite, which achieved a wide pore size distribution (~20 nm) with a surface area greater than the area of pure oxide, Mg-Al (18.5 ± 0.9 m2 g−1) and MgO (104.1 ± 5.2 m2 g−1). The authors also suggested that the decrease in pore sizes caused a reduction in the number of accessible basic sites on the catalyst surface, although they did not quantify the basicity of MgO in their studies. Di Serio et al. [84] and Di Cosimo et al. [31] also reached to similar findings. Another important point is the tolerance to water and free fat acids (FFA) from the raw materials for biodiesel production. Free fatty acids are the result of the hydrolysis of triglycerides and when they are present in greater amounts in oils, with their removal requiring more severe biodiesel synthesis conditions, such as longer reaction time (2–10 h) and higher temperatures (60–100 °C) [2,30,91]. In homogeneous catalysis, the concentration of FFA and water must be less than 0.5% (w/w) to avoid the formation of soaps. Some studies on LDHs confirm their tolerance to water and FFA found in unrefined oils and alcohols, as showed by Yan et al. [9] and Di Serio et al. [84]. This possibility of operating with unrefined oils enhances its competitiveness in the market, since the cost of pre-treatment of wet raw materials represents more than 70% of the total cost of biodiesel production [13]. Di Serio et al. [84] evaluated the influence of water on the catalytic performance of calcined LDH for the production of soybean biodiesel in the presence of high water concentrations (10000 ppm) in the oil. The authors observed that the activity of calcined Mg-AL hydrotalcite was not affected by excess water in the reaction system, the conversion being maintained at 92% even after the addition of water. The possibility of eliminating leaching is another relevant feature in the use of this type of catalyst. Leaching occurs when the basic active species dissolve in alcohol, generating, in addition to the catalyst deactivation, additional costs with the purification of biodiesel and glycerol. However, many studies using mixed oxides as catalysts have shown low levels or absence of leaching [12,14,16]. Hájek et al. [15] studied the leaching of mixed Mg-Fe oxides during transesterification. They found that the catalytic activity was relatively stable, while insignificant amounts of Mg and Fe were identified in liquid products (maximum of 1.1% by weight of catalyst) and that there was no interference in reaction yield. Remarkably, LDH oxides have a versatile character and can be applied both in transesterification for biodiesel production and in smaller scale reactions, such as Knoevenagel condensation between glyceraldehyde acetonide and ethyl acetoacetate [72], aldolic condensation of citral and acetone [47], alkylation methylation of m-cresol [74], allyl benzene isomerization [92], among others. However, in general, catalysts formed by mixed oxides/LDH still need to overcome some operational problems, including: i) catalyst instability on exposure to air, Sankaranarayanan et al. [38] reported the occurrence of hydrokalumite phase reconstruction (CaCO3) formed from the oxide phase together with a calcium carbonate phase, due to the reaction of CaO (one of the phases present in CaAl-LDH) with atmospheric CO2; ii) longer and more rigorous preparation procedures, as a rule, the process until obtaining the mixed oxides comprises the steps of synthesis, aging and heat treatment, with each of these steps required strict control of the preparation variables (temperature, pH, time and others) and iii) high cost of preparation of the catalyst, considering the number of steps necessary for the preparation of the catalyst. In addition to the aspects discussed, LDHs also encompass the advantages and disadvantages associated with the general class of heterogeneous catalysts. Table 6 summarizes the general and typical characteristics associated with the use of LDHs as catalysts. 7 Future trends of heterogeneous catalysis for biodiesel production The use of biodiesel represents an important technological advance that promotes the sustainable development and ensures greater energy security, reducing the world's dependence on fossil fuels. But despite the numerous of advantages associated with the use of biofuels, there are still challenges that biodiesel production needs to overcome for its implementation on a global scale [6,77,93]. One of these challenges is the cost of biodiesel production that is still high compared to conventional diesel. Among the factors that affecting the most the final biodiesel price is the cost of processing. A literature survey indicates that processing costs can be decreased by simplifying operations and eliminating residual flows, as mentioned by, Di Serio et al. [30], Huber et al. [95] and Bournay et al. [96]. The use of heterogeneous catalysts may present itself as a viable solution to overcome this problem, since the classical route, via homogeneous catalysis, involves soluble catalysts, generating water flow capable of carrying waste from the biodiesel industry that can answer negatively to environmental issues. Another drawback of the homogeneous process is the contamination of glycerol by salts and water, requiring the implementation of an acid neutralization step of glycerin to remove sodium soaps that are converted to free fatty acids and separated from glycerin by decantation. Depending on the stages of the biodiesel production process, glycerin can reach a final purity of around 80%, while in the heterogeneous process this purity can reach 98%. Thus, the use of the heterogeneous catalyst eliminates the need to add catalysts to each reaction, since it can be reusable, eliminates the biodiesel purification step and minimizes the glycerol neutralization procedure [97]. The use of heterogeneous catalysts on a commercial scale is already a reality. The French Petroleum Institute (IFP) developed the first biodiesel production process using a heterogeneous catalyst in 2006, marketed by Axens under the trade name Esterfip-H. This process is entirely based on the use of a heterogeneous catalyst composed of a mixed oxide of Zn and Al that promotes the transesterification reaction without catalyst loss. The commercial plant is composed of fixed bed reactors, employing a continuous process where esters and glycerol are separated into a decanter by simple gravity. The purification of esters is carried out in a second reactor, without the use of water and basically consists of vacuum evaporation of excess alcohol. Glycerol is purified by adsorption using an ion exchange resin and, again at this stage, no water is used. Fig. 12 illustrates the main stages of the biodiesel production process via heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysis, in a simplified version. The development of alternatives for biodiesel production is an important ally of improvement of existing production processes. As a next step, a more detailed analysis based on economic and operational criteria should be explored, since steps and operations can be removed and/or added depending on the process chosen to produce biodiesel. In the heterogeneous process, for example, the catalyst can reach the biodiesel producer at a higher price, since the catalyst synthesis step is required, which in general requires time, the use of more than one type of reagent and can employ processes with temperature and pressure control, thus reducing their competitiveness in relation to the use of homogeneous. It is necessary that the impact of these changes be studied and optimized to make the heterogeneous biodiesel industry sustainable. Thus, there is a clear need for research to develop new biodiesel production routes because, even though homogeneous transesterification is a consolidated route, there are still points of improvement that must be considered. Today, there are demands for biofuels mainly in industrialized countries, including the United States, Germany and Brazil, which are the top three technology investors. According to data from the International Energy Agency (IEA) collected by Yesilyurt et al. [98] the world's energy consumption has increased rapidly and will increase about 53% by 2030. Then, the existence of alternative routes, as proposed in this review article, will always be well accepted since the ultimate goal is the continuous improvement of production processes. 8 Conclusion This article presented a general review of the physical and chemical characteristics of mixed oxides, derived from LDHs, and their relationship with catalytic activity in the transesterification reaction for biodiesel production. Data from available literatures considered the parameters associated with the preparation of mixed oxides/LDHs, optimization of reactional parameters of transesterification and aspects related to regeneration, reuse and leaching were presented and discussed. From the reviewed studies, the following conclusions can be made: – The heterogeneous transesterification reaction occurs at specific catalytic sites of the catalyst’s surface, associated with the basic character of the catalyst; – The mixed oxides of LDHs have great potential for application in biodiesel production, because they present tunable basicity via composition modification and synthesis methods; – The surface and textural properties of mixed oxides may be tuned/influenced by the synthesis method (coprecipitation, hydrothermal synthesis, salt-oxide method and others), synthesis conditions (pH, temperature, concentrations, rate of addition of reagents, aging time) and calcination temperature. – It is known that the surface properties of calcined LDHs interfere in the conversion of biodiesel, but the interaction of these properties is not well established and is still a source of discussion among several scientific articles; – Properties such as basicity, specific surface area, pore diameter, pore volume and crystal size play a key role on the catalytic activity of LDHs oxides; – Doping with a third metal can improve the catalytic activity of oxides and potentiate their total basicity; – LDH-derived catalysts can be regenerated and reused relatively easily through well-established and low cost methods; – The leaching process can occur in heterogeneous catalysts, but to a lesser extent with LDH. In view of the above, it is evident that the development of alternatives for biodiesel production is an important ally for improving the existing production process, since technical and economic problems have already been identified in the homogeneous transesterification route. coredata.dc:description: Demand for energy has increased globally due to population growth and socioeconomic development stemming from rapid industrialization and urbanization. This scenario worsens the dependence on energy resources and highlights the question regarding their availability, showing the fragility of non-renewable fossil fuels. In order to supply the growing world demand for energy and respond to environmental concerns, biodiesel was adopted as a mitigating solution to the problems arising from the burning of fossil fuels as it has a biodegradable, renewable and non-toxic character. Recently, many studies have given attention to the heterogeneous catalysts for the production of biodiesel, since some economic and technological problems were recognized in the production via homogeneous reaction. Among the studied catalysts, layered double hydroxides (LDH) have stood out for presenting adjustable properties according to the composition and methods of synthesis, which are directly associated with the structural, morphological and catalytic aspects of their oxides. This review article aims to elucidate the relationship between the structure, basicity, composition and catalytic activity of metal mixed oxides (MMOs) from LDHs. In addition, a comprehensive description is made of the advantages of using MMOs/LDH-based catalysts, of the reaction optimization parameters and of the regeneration and reuse processes of these minerals.
coredata.dc:title: Mixed metal oxides derived from layered double hydroxide as catalysts for biodiesel production
